Pho Ga

Ingredients

Spices

  • 2 Star Anise
  • 1 Tbsp. Corriander Seeds
  • 1 Cinnamon Stick
  • 4 Cloves

Seared Veggies

  • 2 Tbsp. Vegetable Oil
  • 1 yellow onion, peeled, cut in half
  • 1 white onion, peeled, cut in half
  • 13 (or more) grams ginger, unpeeled, cut in half
  • 2 (or 3-4) cloves garlic, peeled, smashed

Broth

  • 8 cups cold water
  • 1 Tbsp. brown sugar
  • 1 bunch fresh cilantro
  • 2 Tbsp. fish sauce
  • 1/2 tsp salt
  • 1 (3-4 lb) chicken

Noodles

  • Your favorite rice noodles (The best option at my store is Amy Chung's. Wide, thick noodles are my preference)

Toppings

  • 1 bunch fresh cilantro (if not lazy, separate leaves
  • 2 bunches green onion, chopped
  • 1 lime, sliced
  • Bean Sprouts
  • Thai Basil, sliced

Instructions

1. Toast spices: Add spices to pressure cooker. Use the "brown" or similar setting at about 350 degrees F or less for about 5 minutes. Set aside.
2. Sear Veggies: Add oil to pressure cooker. Place onions and ginger face-side down in pressure cooker. Use the "brown" or similar setting at about 350 degrees F for about 10-15 minutes. Try not to move the veggies much while browing to form a crust of sorts. When onions/ginger are browned, add garlic, cook for a few minutes.
3. Make broth: Add a couple cups of the water to the pressure cooker, scrape bottom of pan with spatula. Add sugar, fish sauce, and salt - mix, add more of the water if desired. Add chicken - I like to cook breast-side up. Add cilantro around chicken. Add rest of water. Rearrange contents until chicken is completely submerged. Cook under high pressure for 12 minutes - natural pressure release for 20 minutes (I like to make rice noodles as per their instructions near the end of this time), then quick pressure release remaining pressure. Remove chicken. Strain broth from pressure cooker into bowl (don't need the stuff you strain out). Remove chicken skin and cut/rip apart when not too hot.
4. Serve: Add rice noodles to bowls. Add desired chicken and veggies. Add broth to bowls. Squeeze desired lime juice into broth.
